Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase II: Development of Novel Repellents for the Honeybee, Apis Mellifera
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project provides the scientific foundation for a paradigm shift in insect pest control away from traditional insecticides to products that alter insect behavior by manipulating insect chemosensory proteins. We used rational design to isolate compounds that bind to critical insect chemosensory proteins, and are isolating those compounds capable of altering insect behavior. In response to citrus grower demand we have isolated small molecules that have the potential to alter the foraging behavior of the agriculturally and economically significant insect, Apis mellifera (European honeybee). Our final products will be repellents capable of protecting citrus from unwanted pollination. The technologies utilized here are applicable to the development of control products for other insect pest species, including insect carriers of human disease and insect pests of economic, agricultural, or domestic significance.

The broader impacts of this research are avoiding the use of insecticides and expanding our ability to control insect behavior. The initial insect targeted, the European honeybee (Apis mellifera), provides essential pollination that adds an estimated $14 billion annually in value to US crops. However, unwanted honeybee pollination severely decreases the value of mandarin crops, leading to the need for an effective bee repellent that is safe for bees and humans alike. Similar approaches are currently underway to control other important agricultural and public health pests. This project utilizes novel methods with the potential to transform the way insect control products are designed and utilized.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project is to generate a honeybee repellent by manipulating the honeybee chemosensory system, since odors can elicit specific responses in the insect. The repellent was initially intended to prevent unwanted pollination in citrus where it leads to seeded fruit, reducing the market value. However, the repellent can fulfill a far more important role: protecting bees, a crucially important domesticated insect species that is vital to agriculture and apiculture alike, from unwanted exposure to insecticides.

 The use of insecticides remains common practice in modern agriculture, as these chemicals are considered necessary for the very high crop yields required today. Insecticides are thus incorporated into modern integrated pest management (IPM) schemes, and the types and amounts of insecticides applied to modern crops are governed by legislative, financial, and ecological concerns. Nonetheless, the vast majority of crops grown today are exposed to insecticides. One drawback of most widely used insecticides is their lack of target specificity; that is, these chemicals affect a wide variety of animals, ranging from beneficial insects to vertebrates such as fish, mammals, or even humans.

Domesticated honeybees have recently been affected by Colony Collapse Disorder (CCD), a phenomenon in which large numbers of foraging worker bees disappear, causing the colony to suffer unsustainable population losses and thus collapse. Bee pollination is responsible for $15 billion in added crop value (ARS/USDA), demonstrating the commercial need to protect this valuable resource. One potential driver for CCD is exposure to a relatively new class of insecticides called neonicotinoids including, imidacloprid, and fipronil.  In fact use of fipronil has been severely curtailed in France specifically due to concerns over its effect on bees. Thus, an effective repellent that could reduce exposure of honeybees to insecticides would benefit growers and beekeepers alike. Both industries are keenly interested in such a product.

Honeybees use scents as markers while foraging. For example, bees leave short-lived repellent odors on flowers from which they have depleted the nectar in order to make other honeybees avoid these low-value areas. The repellent scent fades while the flower replenishes its nectar, and bees resume their visits.  The use of scent markers is thought to improve foraging efficiency by reducing the time spent on depleted flowers.  The repellent mixture used by honeybees contains 2-heptanone, a compound shown to be a functional repellent for honeybees that is secreted by mandibular glands.  Results obtained using 2-heptanone as a honeybee repellent for plants have shown an extremely short window of activity (< 30 minutes) and thus 2-heptanone is described as “impractical” and “not sufficiently reliable”. However, the data clearly show that honeybees have an olfactory pathway, mediated by 2- heptanone, that results in repellence. We are exploiting this olfactory pathway to develop novel, more effective repellent products.
